CHIEF COMPLAINT OF PRESENT ILLUSTRATIONS:. He is here today for an acne follow-up at the last visit on 03/3/2021. He was prescribed following clindamycin lotion, tretinoin cream, and benzoyl peroxide wash for face, 5 to 10% for chest and back. He denies any irritation, redness, peeling, dryness, or irritation with use of these medications. He washed his face last night and applied the topical antibiotic, Tetracycline, and sunscreen moisture stuff. This morning he washed his skin with the highest level of Benzoyl Peroxide, and put the Tritonol, Tannin, and Protonix topical antibiotics, as well as the sunscreen. There is no change in his acne. He has been doing well with his current treatment. He notes that he has not put much effort into his acne, but that it has not really bothered him. The patient is happy with how things are going. He will send in a new refill for the new medications. The refill will be done once a year. He does not need to complete the refill. If he runs out of medication, he will go
PHYSICAL EXAM
.1. Examination of the acne: There are less than 5 inflammatory papules on the forehead, cheeks, and chin. Mildly controlled in the face. 4 to 5 % benzoyl peroxide wash for face and 5 to 10 % for her chest and back. Scars on the back can handle a little stronger wash. Papules and pustules across the upper back and posterior shoulders. Decreased skin tone with use of the medications. Positive results from the ecchymosis treatment. Positive skin reaction to cortisone shot. The patient is going to walgreens on broad for antacids. They usually last 2-3 months. They also refill the clindamycin lotion with 11 refills and the tretinoin cream with 3 refills.

He was prescribed following clindamycin lotion tretinoin cream 4 to 5 % benzoyl peroxide wash for face and chest and 5 to 10 % for her chest and back. She was advised to continue using the current treatment plan. Based on her exam today, she appears to be doing well with her current medications. Papules and pustules across the upper back and posterior shoulders are scattered inflammatory. I would recommend making any changes to what she is doing based on her physical exam. I am going to send her home with a new refill for the clindycin with 11 refills and then the tretinin cream, with 3 refills that usually are enough for a year if she runs out. She will also bring her Panoxil 10% showering mask down. We discussed the benefits and disadvantages of using a high strength anti-acne medication. I advised her to use a lower strength one. She should continue to use the mask daily for now. If she feels like the acne is improving, I would like to see her back for a refill once a year for her medicine.

note:
CHIEF COMPLAINT

Follow-up.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Maria Martin is a 76-year-old female who presents for follow up. The patient was last seen here for a check-up on 03/05/1946. She is here for follow-up today. The primary care physician notes that her sugars are not very well controlled. She denies any headaches or dizziness. She reports that she has been doing pretty good. Regarding her glimepiride, the patient is still taking 2 mg twice a day, however, the letter from the last visit said that she should increase it to 4 mg once a day. Today, she filled the prescription for 4 mg and will start taking it now. She notes that she is not trying to eat healthier, less carbohydrates, as she does not like pasta. She states that she usually only has 2 slices of bread per day and usually has 2 in the morning. She does not drink much water, but she does drink club soda. She has pain in her hips and upper legs, which she describes as “peripheral neuropathy” and she is trying to get more walking. She also reports that her feet feel like hell
PHYSICAL EXAM

• Cardiovascular: Grade 3/6 systolic ejection murmur.
• Musculoskeletal: Pain to palpation of the bilateral lower extremities, especially the right lower extremity. Right now, the patient is taking 2 pills 2 ml twice a day. The new prescription is for 4 ml 2 ml 2 of this drug.
1. Lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. No wheezes, rales, or rhonchi.
2. Heart sounds normal in all 4 quadrants. No murmurs, gallops, or rubs.
3. Respiratory distress is low. CVA is low at the inhalation stage.

He is on the combination of medications: metoprolol 50 mg once a day, lisinopril with hydrochlorothiazide 20 mg, 25 mg, and amlodipine 10 mg. He drinks carbonated drinks. His blood pressure is 116/105. He has peripheral neuropathy and vascular disease in his legs. He smokes.
ASSESSMENT AND PLANMaria Martin is a 69-year-old female who presents today for a follow-up of her diabetes, hypertension, and vascular disease. Her blood pressure was elevated at 121/80 mm Hg, with a 2-point-plus-1 ejection fraction. Her hemoglobin A1c was 9.9, which is slightly elevated. She should increase her Glimepiride from 2 mg to 4 mg twice a day, but she is still taking 2 mg at this time. The patient will follow up with me in 2 weeks to review her hydration habits. We will also review her lisinopril and amlodipine prescription, as well as her peripheral neuropathy. She is currently on the combination of medications metoprolol 50 mg Once a Day, hydrochlorothiazide 20 mg, 25 mg, and 25 mg once a day. I want her to reduce her intake of alcohol to 0.5 liters per day, limit her alcohol consumption, and limit the use of alcohol. She would like to see her optometrist to reevaluate her cataract surgery in 3 months. She also wants to have her vision checked and have her prescription refilled. We reviewed

dialogue: [doctor] michelle king , date of birth 1/5/1986 , mrn q227631 . new patient visit for acid reflux . past medical history of anxiety and seasonal allergies . [patient] hello , are you mrs. king ? [doctor] i am . [patient] i'm dr. phillips , very nice to meet you . [doctor] you as well . [patient] how can i help you today ? [doctor] well , my primary doctor , dr. scott , he referred me here . [patient] okay . [doctor] i've just got really bad acid reflux . [patient] okay . can you tell me more about it ? [doctor] yeah . so i mean i , right now i take 40 mg of omeprazole twice a day . some days it is fine , but others are just really bad . what do you feel ? [patient] it feels like burning . [doctor] in your chest ? [patient] yes , in my chest and also in my throat . [doctor] in your throat and chest , alright . any difficulty with swallowing ? feels like food or liquids kinda get stuck ? [patient] no . [doctor] okay . that's good . any abdominal pain ? [patient] no , not really . [doctor] nausea or vomiting , changes in bowel movements ? [patient] no . [doctor] constipation , diarrhea , rectal bleeding ? [patient] nope . [doctor] okay . very good . and how long have you had this problem ? [patient] i've had acid reflux since i was around 12 , but it has gotten worse over the past few years . [doctor] okay and how long have you been on the omeprazole ? [patient] on the way it is now i think about a year . [doctor] okay . do you find that it's done anything for you in the past ? i mean i can tell it's helped because some days i'll be fine and then some days i eat something and it feels terrible . are there anything that make your symptoms worse that you can pinpoint like food choices or stress ? sure , probably stress and food choices sometimes . okay . what things bother you ? [patient] spicy foods so i try not to eat them too often but sometimes even drinking a soda can cause it . we do know that caffeine and caffeinated beverages will do that even sodas even just the carbonation can cause that . how about tomato based products or citrus products ? [doctor] yeah sometimes but i still eat them . okay . it's reassuring that you are n't having any difficulty swallowing though . how has your weight been ? pretty stable ? [patient] i would say pretty stable although i have n't had much of an appetite for the past 2 months . i have been under a lot of work stress . [doctor] what do you do for work ? [patient] i'm a paralegal . [doctor] okay and any family history of gi issues ? [patient] my grandmother had esophageal cancer . [doctor] on your mom or dad's side ? [patient] mom's side and my mom had some issues like acid reflux and she was taking some medication that coats the lining of your stomach . [doctor] okay . have you ever had an upper endoscopy ? [patient] i think maybe when i was younger . [doctor] but not in the last 10 years ? [patient] no . [doctor] have you ever tried any medication other than omeprazole ? [patient] at one point i was on omeprazole and ranitidine , it did help . [doctor] but other than that , those are the only medications i have taken . [patient] okay . have a seat here and let me listen to your heart and lungs and then we can talk about a plan for you . [doctor] okay . so normal physical exam per my new patient template except for a well-healed abdominal surgical scar is noted . what's the surgical scar here on your abdomen from ? i always forget about that surgery . i had it when i was a baby . my mom said my intestines were twisted , so i had to have surgery when i was around 1 month old . gotcha , okay . so let's talk about what you have going on . from what you've told me , it sounds like you've had a several year history of gerd , which is the medical term for acid reflux . [patient] and recently your symptoms have been poorly controlled with the omeprazole 40 mg twice daily . you've been having heartburn despite taking this medication , correct ? [doctor] yes . and you've identified trigger foods like spicy foods , carbonated beverages , citrus , and tomato based foods , but you have n't cut these foods out of your diet completely yet . [patient] so the first thing i'd try is changing your diet because these foods can exacerbate your gerd even though you're taking the ppi . [doctor] okay , yeah , i could definitely do a better job of avoiding those foods . [patient] great . so stress is another trigger that we need to address . high stress can cause worsening of your symptoms . [doctor] yeah , stress and anxiety are definitely big problems for me . so working on that may help with your gerd . additionally we can consider trying a different ppi since the only one you've tried up to this point is omeprazole . if you're okay with this , we can switch your omeprazole to nexium . that's fine with me , i'm definitely open to trying whatever . perfect . i will send a prescription for nexium 40 mg twice daily to your pharmacy on file . i also recommend that you have a procedure called a egd or upper endoscopy to look for potential causes of the gerd . we sedate you and then pass a small camera through your mouth down your throat , through your stomach and end in the small intestines . [patient] we would look for any ulcers or signs of precancerous or cancerous conditions that we can take biopsies at the same time if we see anything . [doctor] okay . can i schedule that today ? yeah , you can get scheduled at checkout desk . i'll have you follow up with me in the office for the egd so we can discuss the results and talk about how you're doing with the dietary stress and medication changes . how does all of that sound ? [patient] that sounds good . [doctor] perfect . i will walk you to the check out desk . be sure to call my office and let me know if anything changes or if you have problems before your egd and follow-up appointment . please insert the procedure paragraph in the plan . i suspect that she likely has gerd with underlying functional etiology as well . reassuringly , she has no unintentional weight loss and denies any dysphagia . if her egd is normal and her symptoms persist despite a trial of nexium , we can consider a trial of protonix and obtain a ph impedance study . this will allow us to rule out abnormal acid reflux exposure and to decipher between a functional etiology and hypersensitivity .
note:
CHIEF COMPLAINT NAME: Michelle KingAGE: 39-year-old female.HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS: Mother-of-three. She is a paralegal. She reports that she has been having really bad acid reflux since she was around 12 years old. Her primary care physician referred her here from Dr. Scott. She has been taking 40 mg of omeprazole twice a day, which has been effective on occasion, but she notes that it has not always been 100% effective. She states that some days she is fine with the medication and others she feels terrible. She denies abdominal pain, changes in bowel movements, constipation, diarrhea, or rectal bleeding. Her symptoms can be traced back to food choices and stress. She believes that spicy foods and carbonated drinks can be problematic for her. She tries not to eat them too often but adds that drinking a soda can cause her to get worse. The patient has a family history of esophageal cancer on her mother's side and her grandmother had some issues with esophagitis. She had an upper endoscopy when she was younger, but not in the last 10 years. For now, she has not needed an upper
PHYSICAL EXAM


• Cardiovascular: Stable. No murmurs, gallops, or rubs.
• Musculoskeletal: Trace lower extremity edema. There is a surgical scar on the abdomen from when he was a baby. He had an upper endoscopy. He's fine now. He takes 40 mg of omeprazole twice a day. He doesn't have much of an appetite. He has been under a lot of work stress recently. He drinks carbonated soft drinks. He avoids spicy foods. His grandmother had esophageal cancer. She was taking medication that coats the lining of the stomach.
objective_results: #####EMPTY#####.7071070710#. We are going to discuss acid reflux with dr. phillips. He will listen to the heart and lungs and discuss a treatment plan with the patient. The patient is a paralegal. His grandmother had esophageal cancer and he has family history of gi issues. His mother-in-law had some issues. He is taking medication that coats the lining of the stomach. He drinks carbonated drinks. He has not had an upper endoscopy in the last 10 years. He does not have any constipation or bowel movements.
ASSESSMENT AND PLANningMichelle King presents for a new patient visit for acid reflux. She has had symptoms since she was around 12 years old and her symptoms have gotten worse over the past few years. She is a paralegal and has been under a lot of work stress. We discussed treatment options today, including limiting spicy foods to 40 mg of omeprazole twice a day. She can exacerbate her symptoms with carbonated foods, but I've been unable to identify a trigger that would cause nausea or vomiting. I advised her to try a low-calorie diet, avoid citrus fruits and spices, and limit her intake of alcohol. We also discussed possible endoscopy options, such as uroscopy or gastric bypass surgery. All questions were answered.

note:
CHIEF COMPLAINT OF PRESENT ILLNESS: Michelle King is a 39-year-old female with a history of quadriplegia due to prior spinal cord injury. She was admitted to the hospital on 6/29/2020 and discharged on 7/2/2021. The patient was experiencing increasing concerns for spasms and lightheadedness, significant constipation, reported diaphoresis, labile blood pressure, headache, and vomiting, and was initially seen in the emergency department where she was febrile and had significantly elevated white blood cell count of 23,000. There were concerns for an ongoing urinary tract infection, but she was treated with i.v. antibiotic therapy and was eventually discharged after clinical improvement of her symptoms. She believes that she was constipated at the time she was there and that this was the cause of her blood pressure being so high. When she returned home, she had a massive poop and she felt much better. She denies an infection. 
objective_exam: #####EMPTY#####.showed significant constipation. Decreased white blood cell count of 23,000. Normal white cell count was the only thing that they were concerned about. Automatic dysreflexia did not affect the white count. Positive PKU test was normal. Negative PSA test indicated pain to palpation of the right knee without pain. No pain or discomfort. #####Upper extremity: #####Urine: No uvula edema. Positive pitting reflexes. Negative Homan's sign. Positive rectal tenderness. No rebound or guarding. 
RESULTS: White blood cell count of 23,000. Urinary tract infection: Not identified. She was treated with i.v. and was released on 7/2/2021. She has a suprapubic catheter. She is in good health. Her mobility is good. She can use her mobility scooter. She uses a walker. She does not have any fractures or arthritis. She exercises regularly. Her right leg is immaculate. Her left leg is well-maintained. She had a mild case of arthritis. The white cell count was elevated in the last year. Her arthritis was normal.
ASSESSMENT AND PLANMichelle King is a 39-year-old female with a history of quadriplegia due to prior spinal cord injury. She presents today to follow up regarding her concerns. She was admitted to hospital on 6/29/2021 and was discharged on 7/2/2020. She presented today with an elevated white blood cell count of 23,000, fever, labile blood pressure, headache, nausea, abdominal pain, and vomiting. There were concerns of an ongoing urinary tract infection, but she was treated with i.v. antibiotics and was eventually discharged after clinical improvement of her symptoms. Her white cell count was slightly elevated but did not appear to be related to infection. She is constipated, but this appears to have been rectal related. We will order a stool culture to rule out any bacterial infections. She should follow up with me in 2 weeks to check on her progress. If she continues to worsen, we may need to consider further imaging or a CT or MRI to evaluate for possible blood clots. I advised her to drink plenty of fluids and keep a lid on her hydrated. I also advised her not to eat or drink much at this time of the day due to the heat

note:
CHIEF COMPLAINT OF PRESENT ILLNESS: Ashley James. She is a 14-year-old female who is previously healthy, now here for evaluation of abnormal renal ultrasound with an atrophic right kidney. The patient reports she came home 1 day sick with abdominal pain. She initially thought she had an appendix. She was seen by her primary care physician, who treated her for a stomach virus, gave her fluids and sent her back home. The next day she was twice as bad as the first day, but did not improve. She then followed up with her secondary care provider, who was out of town and unable to see her, and they stayed in Atlanta for 4 days, where they treated her and kept her for further evaluation. She denies fever, pain, and burning. She has not had any more throwing up or anything since then, but she still complains about a lot of pain in her stomach. Dr. Rodgers explains that she was found to have a small kidney on one side, but they did more testing and found that one kidney was bigger and they called it atrophic, so they did an ultrasound and that is where they found the smaller kidney. She states that she has been doing well since that time. She also
PHYSICAL EXAM
• Cardiovascular: 2/6 systolic ejection murmur.
• Musculoskeletal: There is a lot of pain to palpation of the right lower extremity. The patient is being seen by dr. rogers today. He will complete an exam of her heart and lungs. and finally discuss with the patient the findings of the previous review that were inconclusive and were of no significance to the patient at this time. They were, however, noted as bilaterally, in addition to the bilateral lower extremities examination, which is itself nonspecifically positive sign of kidney failure.
RESULTS: Normal renal ultrasound with an atrophic right kidney. One of the kidneys was smaller than the other. There was an infection present. The primary care physician was out of town on vacation and didn't see the patient. The next day she was still sick and in pain. Her lymph nodes were swollen. She complained of a lot of pain in her stomach. She was admitted to the hospital in Atlanta and stayed there for 4 days. She has not had any more throwing up or anything since. The doctors reviewed her records and found that the other kidney was bigger and worked out that it was atrophic.
ASSESSMENT AND PLANningAshley James is a 14-year-old female who is previously healthy. She presents today for evaluation of abnormal renal ultrasound with an atrophic right kidney. We discussed the diagnosis and treatment options today. I explained that her symptoms are consistent with an infection. She will follow up with her primary care physician in 2 weeks to check on her progress. At that time, I will complete an exam of her heart and lungs and then we will move from there. The goal is to have her discharged home with no further treatment. We also discussed the possibility of performing a kidney biopsy. This procedure was discussed with the patient. All questions were answered.

[patient] no , i also wear the left sometimes , the right is just worse but the splint helps . both have really gotten worse over the last month and i broke them my right wrist was definitely in worse shape . i've also been having some mild stiffness in my neck too . i hit my head during the accident and they told me it was a contusion . [doctor] and where would you say the tingling and numbness is ? [patient] on this side , it goes from here and here up to about here on the other side , it's from here to here . [doctor] i see . so on the right side you're pointing from the middle and ring finger all the way up the forearm and on the left the symptoms extend from the pinky and ring finger and is there any pain or just tingling and numbness ? it's mainly just sore , sometimes they throb but overall they feel weaker too especially when i'm using them . the tingling happens more when they hurt , but when it goes away , the tingling is dull . [patient] and when do you feel these symptoms ? well , really i guess just more so at night and they come and go throughout the day . [doctor] okay and do you experience any loss of sensation in your hands or fingers ? [patient] like feeling something , no , not that i can really think of though in general they maybe less sensitive than they should be but i can still feel they also gave me some nerve pain medicine , but i have n't been taking it like i should . [doctor] and are you still on the coreg for hypertension and the lexapro for anxiety ? [patient] yes , i'm still taking those . i had prediabetes too , but i got it under control by changing my diet . [doctor] and no history of thyroid issues , correct ? [patient] no . [doctor] ri thank you mr. cook okay first we'll go over your review of systems correct me if i'm wrong in any of this constitutional you have fatigue and weight gain gi you have excessive appetite and bloating eyes have floaters , cardiovascular shows shortness of breath and leg swelling , endocrine , you're always hungry , skin , you have some nailbed changes , dryness , and itching , musculoskeletal , you have gout and muscle pain , and the remainder of the review of systems is negative . [patient] yeah , that's all correct . [doctor] alright we are going to go ahead and do the neurologic examination . let's look at the right hand first . can you feel this ? [patient] yeah , but a little less on these two fingers . [doctor] sensation is normal except pinprick sensation diminished in the third and fourth fingers on the right and how about on the left ? [patient] yeah but these two are little less . [doctor] sensation is decreased in the fourth and fifth fingers on the left . okay , let's test your reflexes now . reflexes are 1+ and symmetric . 2+ knees , toes are downgoing bilaterally . alright , i'm going to tap on your right wrist . do you feel anything ? [patient] yeah , it feels like a zing of my wrist and something into my elbow too . [doctor] and how about the left side ? [patient] yeah , same on that side too . [doctor] tinel's sign positive at both wrists and both elbows . rest of exam is normal . alright so what i am seeing today is bilateral carpal tunnel syndrome or potentially this could also be bilateral cubital tunnel syndrome . however , your symptom presentation suggests bilateral carpal tunnel syndrome as the nerves in your wrist are aggravated by your past trauma . this is causing the pain and tingling you were describing to me . okay . so how we make it better ? first , i want to determine exactly where the nerve irritation is coming from . we will need to schedule you for a nerve test , which is called an emg test . they will measure the responsiveness of your nerves to truly pinpoint where you're having your issues . [patient] that sounds fine to me . [doctor] great . after the tests are complete , you can return here for a follow-up visit . if you're still having symptoms , we can consider a referral to our hand clinic possibly for injections or carpal tunnel release surgery . you could also refer , we could also refer you to an orthopedist for the same treatment . [patient] sounds good document . [doctor] alright keep wearing your splints and i will see you after those studies . [patient] thank you .
note:
CHIEF COMPLAINT

Bilateral wrist and elbow numbness and tingling.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Mr. Martinez is a 60-year-old right-handed male who presents today for evaluation of bilateral wrist neuromusculoskeletal syndrome. He sustained an injury in a car accident last December and required surgery on his right wrist and left elbow. He reports an increase in numbness in both of his hands since the wounds healed. He wears a splint on the right wrist, but notes that the left wrist also gets worse. He experiences numbness more at night and the symptoms come and go throughout the day. He denies any loss of sensation in his hands or fingers. The numbness is localized to the right hand and extends from the middle finger all the way up the forearm and on the left the symptoms extend from the pinky and ring finger to the left hand, sometimes they throb, but overall they feel weaker when he is using them. Mr. Martinez states that he has been taking Neurontin, which he believes he has not been using properly. He also reports mild stiffness in his neck after the injury. He notes that he hit his head during the accident, but
PHYSICAL EXAM

Neurological
- Orientation: Alert and oriented x3. Speech is clear and fluent. Gait is steady. Reflexes are 1+ and symmetric. 2+ knees, toes are downgoing bilaterally.
Nervous System
- Review of Systems: Decreased sensation in the right thumb and index finger. Sensation is decreased in the 4th and 5th fingers. Decreased pinprick sensation on the left thumb. Fatigue, weight gain, endocrine, you're always hungry, skin, you have some nailbed changes, dryness, and itching. Musculoskeletal
- Examination of System: Negative. No gout or muscle pain.
objective_results: #####EMPTY#####. We are going to do the neurologic examination of the right hand and review the review of systems. These reveal normal bony reflexes with good bony alignment. 2+ knees and 2+ toes are downgoing bilaterally. There is no evidence of any fracture or osteoarthritis. The review of the systems is negative. The patient is still on the coreg for hypertension and the lexapro for anxiety. He had prediabetes and changes in his diet before the accident. He is taking the drug Lexapro to prevent hypothyroidism.
ASSESSMENT AND PLANningMr. Cook is a 60-year-old right handed male who presents for evaluation of bilateral wrist tingling and numbness. He had a car accident in December of last year. He is currently in a splint on his right wrist. The symptoms have worsened since his car accident. He has been taking anti-inflammatory medications as needed. We reviewed the patient's examination and radiographic findings today. bilateral carpal tunnel syndrome is likely the cause of his symptoms. We will order a tetracycline tester to evaluate for responsiveness. He will also follow up with a neurologist for further evaluation. If his symptoms do not improve with the tester, we may need to consider further treatment such as a corticosteroid injection or surgical intervention. The patient is advised to discontinue the use of anti-inflammatories and anti-anxiety medications.

note:
HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS Shirley Taylor is a 60-year-old right-handed female new patient referred by dr. jacob ward for evaluation of bilateral hand numbness and tingling. She reports she has had numbness in her right hand and right wrist since last December when she broke her wrists. She is wearing a splint only on her right wrist. There is no left wrist numbness, but she notices it more with the right one. The numbness has been present since December of last year, but the right wrist has improved since she broke them. She notices numbness from the middle and ring finger all the way up to her forearm and left wrist, pinky and the ring finger, but not the middle rn. She also reports right wrist pain, soreness, and throbbing, but overall they feel weaker when she is using them. The pain is mainly at night and then changes to dullness throughout the day. She describes the numbness as “come and goes” and “it just kind of comes and goes all day” with no specific activity.“The numbness” is mainly on the right side of her hands, with the exception of the pinky

CHIEF COMPLAINT NAME: Stephanie MoralesAGE: 44-year-old femaleHISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS: 6 weeks post right medial unicompartmental arthroplasty.REVIEW OF SYSTEMS: [1] Musculoskeletal: No pain. [2] Neurological: No numbness on the right side of the knee. [3] Denies any numbness. [4] Orthopaedic: Denies right knee dysfunction. [5] Genitourinary: Reports right knee swelling. [6 weeks postoperative: Reports gait with decreased velocity using an assist device. [10 weeks postop: Reports mild swelling. “11.5 months after surgery, patient reports right knee pain with occasional aches and pains.” The patient is still unable to return to work as she is unable to go back yet due to her current position. However, she is being considered for a telemedicine visit in 6 weeks. The visit will be to check in and assess how she is doing and make sure things are progressing. The patient will be able to resume her current work schedule then.
PHYSICAL EXAM

Neurological
- Orientation: Alert and oriented x3. Normal reflex time is returned at 6 weeks. The incision looks nice. There is mild swelling along the medial aspect of the knee. The area of numbness will get smaller as the nerves that innervate the skin across the knee heal.
Respiratory
- Auscultation of Lungs: Lungs are clear and clear bilaterally. No wheezes, rales, or rhonchi.
Cardiovascular19th trimester assessment: No murmurs, gallops, or rubs. 2/6 systolic ejection murmur. Otherwise, regular rate and rhythm.


RESULTS

X-rays of the right knee were obtained and reviewed in office today. These reveal no fracture or osteoarthritis. There is mild swelling. The incision is clean and well-maintained. The area of numbness on the right side will get smaller as the nerves across the skin across the knee heal. The normal reflex time is returned at 6 weeks. The appointment with the surgeon will take place in 6 weeks and the appointment will be reviewed in 3 months. The patient will be able to drive after the surgery. The visit will be scheduled on the doctor’s request. The office will arrange a telemedicine visit.
ASSESSMENT AND PLANMedical Reasoning: The patient is currently 6 weeks status post Right medial unicompartmental arthroplasty. There is still some numbness on this side of the knee. The incision looks nice and the incisional scar is well-formed. The patient will continue to work on her strength, range of motion, and endurance as the nerves across the knee heal. She should avoid lifting greater than 5 pounds and no standing or sitting longer than half an hour without assistance for the next 6 weeks. The return to driving is determined by when she feels safe to be able to do so. She will contact her employer to arrange a telemedicine visit to check in and make sure things are progressing. We will talk again in 6 weeks and discuss her job again at that time.
